item.title: Trump wisely takes a go-slow approach to Venezuelan democracy
item.description: Regenerating constitutional democracy in Venezuela would require intensive U.S. military involvement.

item.title: Running deficits larger than during the Great Depression is reckless
item.description: A bipartisan group of House members are rallying behind a welcome and reasonable target for 2030.

item.title: Why people see what they want in protests and police shootings
item.description: Reflexively siding with or against law enforcement is folly.

item.title: No blood for oil? That doesn’t make sense for Venezuela.
item.description:
Early on Jan 3, news broke that Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro had been captured by U.S. troops and was being flown to New York to stand trial. Later that day, President Donald Trump said the United States would take control of Venezuela’s massive oil reserves. Protests erupted almost immediately, reviving the Iraq War–era slogan, “no blood for oil.”
Host Megan McArdle breaks down the long, troubled history of Venezuelan oil and explains why the U.S. has a responsibility to help rebuild the country's economy.

item.title: The Chicago Teachers Union’s New Year’s resolution: more mediocrity
item.description: If the union really cares about justice, it should focus on teaching students how to read and write.

item.title: A president who treats Washington like his chew toy
item.description: Trump’s triumphal arch will be harder to undo than his gilding of the Oval Office.
